clinical_study.brief_title: Prediction of TEI Success in Sciatica
clinical_study.official_title: Prediction Of Transforaminal Epidural Injection Success in Sciatica

brief_summary.textblock:
Rationale: Treatment with transforaminal epidural injections is part of usual care in patients suffering from sciatica. However, not all patients experience a satisfactory result from this treatment and it is unclear what percentage of patients responds well and if any clinical or radiological factors exist that predict a positive response.
Objectives:
Primary: to determine the average leg pain score two weeks after treatment with TEI in patients with sciatica due to LDH and due to spinal stenosis.
Secondary: to determine the average score for leg pain, back pain, functionality, anxiety and depression, pain coping, patient satisfaction and overall health status postprocedural and at 2 weeks and 6 weeks after TEI, and to explore radiological and clinical factors that predict TEI success.
Study design: Prospective cohort study
Study population: Patients that are scheduled for TEI as part of usual care suffering from a first episode of sciatica
Main study parameters/endpoints: The mean leg pain score at 2 weeks after treatment with TEI. Leg pain, back pain, functionality, patient satisfaction, anxiety and depression, pain coping and quality of life post-procedural and at 2 and 6 weeks follow-up.

arm_group.description: Patients with a lumbar disc herniation on MRI and consistent with clinical findings are screened if they have an appointment at the pain clinic for treatment with a transforaminal epidural injection.
Patients with a lumbar spinal stenosis on MRI and consistent with clinical findings are screened if they have an appointment at the pain clinic for treatment with a transforaminal epidural injection.

intervention.description: Injections above L3 will contain 1,5 ml lidocaine 1% and 10 mg dexamethasone and injections at L3 or below will contain 1,5 ml lidocaine 2% and 40mg methylprednisolone acetate in accordance with current Dutch anesthesiologic guidelines for usual care.

study_pop.textblock: Patients suffering from sciatica due to lumbar disc herniation or spinal stenosis that have a scheduled appointment for treatment with TEI are screened to be candidates for this study. If the patient fulfills the inclusion and exclusion criteria the patient can participate in this study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of first episode of sciatica secondary to lumbar disc herniation or spinal stenosis
- Diagnosis confirmed by Magnetic Resonance Imaging
- Access to e-mail
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age under 18 years
- Severe scoliosis
- History of back surgery
- Epidural injection received in 12 months before date of participation
- Circumstances that prevent treatment with Transforaminal Epidural Injection (e.g. use of anticoagulants that cannot be temporarily discontinued)
- Pregnancy
